Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Stream Consumers and Lotic Ecosystem Rates (SCALER): Scaling from Centimeters to Continents
Award.AbstractNarration: The overarching question that Scale, Consumers and Lotic Ecosystem Rates (SCALER) will address is: How can small-scale ecological experiments be applied to understand the behavior of entire ecological systems? Funds are provided to address:: 1) How should measures of fundamental properties of streams and effects of animals on those properties be scaled up to predict ecosystem characteristics of stream networks. 2) How do patterns of scaling compare across the wide array of ecological systems (from tundra to tropical forest) that occurs across North American? The SCALER experiment will be done in tropical forest, temperate mountainous forest, prairie, northern boreal evergreen forest, and tundra areas. Streams in each of these five areas will be examined at scales of centimeters to 10?s of meters in small, medium and large streams. Rates of stream metabolism (photosynthesis and respiration) and nutrient uptake will be measured as well as the way these rates respond to animal exclusions (used to mimic loss of animal diversity in streams). These local results will be linked to the scale of watersheds and regions by modeling. Watershed scale predictions will be verified by broader, but less intensive sampling. Mechanistic explanation of how ecological measurements and experiments in streams can be scaled to watersheds will be provided. This scaling will be characterized in each of the five areas across the continent to explore how scaling differs across natural habitats. The knowledge that will be generated by this project is essential to quantify controls on stream ecosystem processes as well as to manage human impacts on entire watersheds. The experimental and modeling results will be relevant to general ecology because few nested, and experimental and theoretically coupled scaling experiments have been undertaken in any environment. Results will inform those involved in conservation, management, and restoration of freshwater resources. Resource managers will gain a quantitative rationale and framework to link local measurements to regional patterns. The highly collaborative team will train six graduate students, five post doctoral students, and mentor three early career faculty members. Additional collaborations will be encouraged to collaborate and perform similar projects at additional sites through workshops related to the objectives and research design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Scale, Consumers, and Lotic Ecosystem Rates (SCALER) project was designed to examine whether small scale ecological experiments in streams could be used to understand stream ecosystem structure and function at larger, regional scales. The major goal of the project was to provide insight in to how relatively small-scale experiments that are commonly performed at individual sites can be extrapolated to larger scales such as river networks, and what abiotic variables are most important for scaling up models of ecosystem function from reach to network. The study sites encompassed five biomes, each of which had six sites with measurements nested at the microhabitat and reach scales, linked to watershed models. Synoptic sampling at each site was also done to characterize watershed-scale patterns. Rates of metabolism and nutrient uptake and responses to experimental consumer exclusions were measured at micro (0.1 m) and reach (100 m) scales. Experiments occurred over three years. The SCALER project was a large, collaborative effort involving numerous institutions; SIU’s primary role was to process, identify, and measure stream invertebrate samples collected as part of the experimental manipulations at each site.

Processing of the invertebrate samples at SIU generated a large database of stream invertebrate communities for the 5 original study sites, including tropical rain forest, Appalachian Mountains, tallgrass prairie, and arctic tundra, plus two additional sites in temperate rainforest (Oregon) and tropical northern Australia. Current synthesis efforts are aimed at examining relationships between invertebrate communities and physical variables across sites. Results of the consumer manipulation experiments indicate that consumer (e.g., fish) effects on ecosystem structure (e.g., invertebrate diversity) and function (e.g., nutrient uptake and metabolism) are context dependent and vary considerably in space and time. We examined physical variables at multiple scales across the sites and found that canopy cover and water depth varied significantly at watershed, stream order, and reach scales, while wetted width varied at just two scales (stream order and reach). Sediment size was largely unexplained. Similarly, predictions by drainage area varied among attributes; depending on the watershed, increases in wetted width and water depth with drainage area were either linear, logarithmic, or power relationships, whereas variation in sediment size was independent of drainage area. During the course of this project, we also developed new and improved methods to calculate nutrient uptake and metabolism in streams. A major product of SCALER was the development of the stream biome gradient concept.  This conceptual model can be used to predict large scale biological patterns in streams along climate (temperature and precipitation) gradients and provides a mechanism for aquatic scientists to understand how results from one biome might apply to a less-studied biome, broaden other models of stream ecosystems, and should lead to better large-scale management and conservation of streams.
